awd_titl_txt: Achieving Challenging Transformations with 1,2,3-Triazole Based Novel Metal Catalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by the Chemical Synthesis program of the Chemistry Division. Professor Xiaodong Shi of University of South Florida develops new catalytic systems for the synthesis of azaborine compounds and for the C-H bond activation. The inclusion of boron in organic compounds (compounds composed largely of carbon and hydrogen) is important in biomedical applications and optoelectronic materials. However, boron is not part of most organic compounds. To address this difficulty, this project is developing new ways of inserting a boron-nitrogen unit into organic compounds. In addition, these methods devised are being modified so that they can be used to increase the reactivity of organic molecules. This latter goal is very important in many chemical processes including the conversion of natural gas into valuable chemical feedstocks. The project also brings undergraduate students into research early in their college careers. This permits them to work with graduate and postdoctoral students in a multidisciplinary project that prepares them for graduate education and/or careers in chemistry. 

This project focuses on new catalysts based on triazole complexes of gold, palladium, iron, cobalt and nickel as well as the synthesis of azaborine and asymmetric methods toward C-H bond activation. Various catalyst structures are examined, and the most promising ones are studied further using X-ray crystallography, NMR spectroscopy and mass spectrometry. The reaction mechanism of each catalyst is investigated using typical kinetic analyses including NMR spectroscopy and reactive IR. The project provides training of undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students in multidisciplinary catalytic science. In addition, an outreach program to undergraduates is providing a platform to gain research experience for their future career development.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The general scheme of this past support focused on PI’s continuing efforts for the investigation on the coordination ability between 1,2,3-triazole derivatives with transition metal and development of new catalysts for challenging transformations.  This specific aims for the proposal were:

1) Application of triazole-gold catalyzed hydroboration as an effective novel strategy for the preparation of

various synthetically challenging azaborine derivatives;

2) Investigation of triazole-Pd complexes for oxidative C-H activation and the application of dynamic triazole ligands for site selective and stereo-selective C-H activation;

3) Exploration of triazoles for base-metal (Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) coordination to elucidate basic binding properties of the complexes for the discovery of novel base-metal catalysts.

 

The investigation on all three areas have been conducted as proposed.  It has been very fruitful with 25 publications over a four-year period (2017-2021, 2 Chem; 1 Nat. Commun.; 1 J. Am. Chem. Soc.; 3 Angew. Chem. Int. Ed.; 1 ACS Catal.; 2 Cell Rep. Phys. Sci.; 2 Chem. Sci.; 2 Chem. Commun.; 2 Chem. Eur. J.; 3 Org. Lett.; 2 Org. Biomol. Chem. etc.). Notably, our investigations in this focused area have been instrumental and systematic.  First, we developed a comprehensive synthetic strategy for various substituted triazole with an understanding of stereochemistry and electronic influence on selectivity and nitrogen binding ability.  Second, the discovery of triazole-Au(I) (TA-Au) binding led to the introduction of a new concept of dynamic L-ligand, [PPh3Au(TA)]+, with significantly improved gold catalyst stability for challenging transformations.  Third, to further improve the triazole gold reactivity, the combination of TA-Au and Lewis acid was developed, a result which significantly increased catalyst reactivity and facilitated many new challenging transformations by tuning the balance of catalyst reactivity and stability.  In addition to triazole-gold (TA-Au), we also explored other interesting triazole-metal systems with unique properties, including A) triazole-iridium photocatalysts, B) triazole as directing group for selective C-H activation, using Pd, Ni, and Co metal cation coordination, and C) triazole derivatives as a new class of probes for bio-sensing, molecular recognition.  

 

Besides the continuing development of new reactivity with 1,2,3-triazole gold catalyst (TA-Au), we have successfully moved the TA ligands to other areas.  Two recent successes from last proposal period were 4-amino-benzoltriazole (ABTA) as the removable directing group for aerobic C-H olefination (the first time ever reported) and triazole-olefin for new stable Ru-metathesis catalysts.  Two manuscripts are currently under preparation.  In addition, tri-dentated triazole ligands have been successfully developed with X-ray obtained through coordination with Ni, Mn, Cu and Ni, as proposed in the research plan.  Investigation on the reactivity of these new catalytic systems are currently undergoing.  Promising new catalytic system are expected with PI’s continuous efforts on this direction.

 


Last Modified: 11/05/2021
Modified by: Xiaodong Shi
por.por_txt_cntn:
The general scheme of this past support focused on PI’s continuing efforts for the investigation on the coordination ability between 1,2,3-triazole derivatives with transition metal and development of new catalysts for challenging transformations.  This specific aims for the proposal were:

1) Application of triazole-gold catalyzed hydroboration as an effective novel strategy for the preparation of

various synthetically challenging azaborine derivatives;

2) Investigation of triazole-Pd complexes for oxidative C-H activation and the application of dynamic triazole ligands for site selective and stereo-selective C-H activation;

3) Exploration of triazoles for base-metal (Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) coordination to elucidate basic binding properties of the complexes for the discovery of novel base-metal catalysts.

 

The investigation on all three areas have been conducted as proposed.  It has been very fruitful with 25 publications over a four-year period (2017-2021, 2 Chem; 1 Nat. Commun.; 1 J. Am. Chem. Soc.; 3 Angew. Chem. Int. Ed.; 1 ACS Catal.; 2 Cell Rep. Phys. Sci.; 2 Chem. Sci.; 2 Chem. Commun.; 2 Chem. Eur. J.; 3 Org. Lett.; 2 Org. Biomol. Chem. etc.). Notably, our investigations in this focused area have been instrumental and systematic.  First, we developed a comprehensive synthetic strategy for various substituted triazole with an understanding of stereochemistry and electronic influence on selectivity and nitrogen binding ability.  Second, the discovery of triazole-Au(I) (TA-Au) binding led to the introduction of a new concept of dynamic L-ligand, [PPh3Au(TA)]+, with significantly improved gold catalyst stability for challenging transformations.  Third, to further improve the triazole gold reactivity, the combination of TA-Au and Lewis acid was developed, a result which significantly increased catalyst reactivity and facilitated many new challenging transformations by tuning the balance of catalyst reactivity and stability.  In addition to triazole-gold (TA-Au), we also explored other interesting triazole-metal systems with unique properties, including A) triazole-iridium photocatalysts, B) triazole as directing group for selective C-H activation, using Pd, Ni, and Co metal cation coordination, and C) triazole derivatives as a new class of probes for bio-sensing, molecular recognition.  

 

Besides the continuing development of new reactivity with 1,2,3-triazole gold catalyst (TA-Au), we have successfully moved the TA ligands to other areas.  Two recent successes from last proposal period were 4-amino-benzoltriazole (ABTA) as the removable directing group for aerobic C-H olefination (the first time ever reported) and triazole-olefin for new stable Ru-metathesis catalysts.  Two manuscripts are currently under preparation.  In addition, tri-dentated triazole ligands have been successfully developed with X-ray obtained through coordination with Ni, Mn, Cu and Ni, as proposed in the research plan.  Investigation on the reactivity of these new catalytic systems are currently undergoing.  Promising new catalytic system are expected with PI’s continuous efforts on this direction.
